abstract.p: Spanish conquerors of the New World employed principles of organization perfected during the 770-year Reconquest of Spain by the Moors. Conquistadors organized themselves as compañas (companies), whose members shared the hardships and the profits of their military expeditions. Each compaña was headed by a captain who had royal authorization for conquest, making him a partner of the crown, which received one-fifth of all spoils (quinto). The remainder was divided among the compaña. The captain, who raised private financing to buy ships, supplies, and arms (crossbows, arquebuses, and cannons), received a fixed share. A peon (common soldier) received one share of the remainder; a caballero (horseman) received two—the second for his horse.

sec.p: At issue: European dominance in the American hemisphere
Location: Caribbean Islands, Mexico, and Peru
Combatants: Spanish vs. Aztecs and Incas

Principal commanders: Spanish, Hernán Cortés (1485–1547), Francisco Pizarro (1476–1541); Aztec, Montezuma (Motecuhzoma) II (1480?-1520), Cuauhtemóc (Guatemotzín) (1495?-1525); Inca, Atahualpa (1500?-1533), Manco Capac (1505?-1544), Tupac Amaru (d. 1572)
Principal battles: Cholula, La Noche Triste, Siege of Tenochtitlán, Cajamarca, Cuzco
Result: Spanish victory and decline of Central and South American Indian civilizations

sec.p: Only a century old at conquest, the Aztec Empire was very different from that of the Incas. The Aztecs, who conquered south central Mexico, regarded war as desirable. They allowed autonomy to so-called “enemies of the house” who participated in scheduled conflicts known as Flower Wars, in which Aztec warriors, armed with obsidian-bladed clubs, bows, darts, and slings and arrayed in the regalia of the military orders of the Eagle, Jaguar, Serpent, or a similar symbol, took prisoners for sacrifice. Unlike the Aztecs, the Inca Empire was highly centralized, and its soldiers fought in disciplined formations. War was a means to an end, not an end in itself. Their Andean empire expanded because its Imperial Mummy Cult allowed Inca rulers to keep their property in death, forcing new rulers to conquer new territories.

sec.title: Action
sec.p: On February 19, 1519, Hernán Cortés sailed from Cuba on an illegal expedition to Mexico with six hundred men, twenty horses, and ten cannons. At Cozumel, he rescued a castaway, Jerónimo de Aguilar, who knew the Mayan language. On the Tabascan coast, Cortés skirmished with that tribe before concluding an alliance and taking a woman, Malinche, as his mistress and interpreter. On April 21, Cortés landed and founded a town, Villa Rica de Vera Cruz, thus legalizing his expedition. Montezuma, informed of the Spaniard’s arrival, feared that this was the predicted return of Quetzalcóatl and sent ambassadors. Playing the god, Cortés demanded and received gold, which he sent to Holy Roman emperor Charles V (also king of Spain as Charles I), before burning his ships and moving inland. On his march, Cortés defeated the Tlaxcalans, then allied with these Aztec enemies. In Cholula (October 12), suspecting an ambush, he slaughtered that city’s nobility. On November 8, he reached Tenochtitlán, built on an island in Lake Texcoco. Montezuma greeted Cortés, who took the Aztec emperor hostage and ruled through him. In late April, 1520, Cortés returned to the coast to persuade an expedition sent to arrest him to join him instead. He returned to Tenochtitlán on June 24 with 1,300 Spaniards and 2,000 Tlaxcalan troops to discover that his men had slaughtered Aztec nobles at a religious ceremony. The Aztecs then chose Cuauhtemóc as emperor, and Montezuma was killed, either by the Spaniards or his own people. On La Noche Triste (June 30), Cortés and his men fought their way to the mainland. Only 460 Spaniards survived, all wounded. Cortés spent the next several months winning Indian allies, securing his supply lines, and recruiting reinforcements. In December, he returned to Lake Texcoco with 800 Spanish infantry, 100 horsemen, 8 cannons, and a Tlaxcalan army that grew to 100,000. For the Siege of Tenochtitlán (May to August 23, 1521), Cortés had 13 brigantines constructed, blockaded the Aztec city, and destroyed it. Smallpox ravaged the Aztec defenders who, blockaded, could not replace their losses; on August 23, 1521, Cuauhtemóc surrendered to Cortés.

In December, 1531, after two unsuccessful expeditions in 1524–1525 and 1526–1528, Francisco Pizarro sailed south from Panama with a small compaña of 200 men and 27 horses. He arrived on the scene in 1532 as the Inca civil war was ending. The war had begun when the emperor Huáscar attempted to confiscate property of the Imperial Mummies. The emperor’s move was opposed by the administrators of the property who, led by Huáscar’s half-brother Atahualpa, defeated Huáscar and took him prisoner. Pizarro advanced into the highlands toward Cajamarca (1532), where Atahualpa was encamped with his army. Inspired by Cortés’s tactics in Mexico, Pizarro sent a message asking to meet the Inca leader, and laid an ambush for him. Unconcerned, Atahualpa entered the deserted city square borne on his golden litter with his personal guard. The trap was sprung, with cannon fire and horsemen scattering and killing the guards. Pizarro seized Atahualpa and used him as a puppet for Spanish rule. Atahualpa attempted to ransom himself by filling a room with gold, but when it was done, Pizarro executed him. Pizarro then took Cuzco (November, 1533), assisted by Huáscar’s faction, which took revenge on Atahualpa’s followers. From that faction, Pizarro chose Manco Capac as his puppet emperor, but Manco escaped, raised an army, and laid siege to Cuzco for ten months before withdrawing into the Andes. After the siege, the Spanish fought a factional war for control of Cuzco, leading to Pizarro’s assassination in 1541. Pizarro’s brother, Gonzalo Pizarro, regained power, even murdering a viceroy, but stopped short of declaring himself king. Peru remained unsettled until the arrival in 1569 of Viceroy Francisco de Toledo, who finished the Inca conquest when a Spanish force took the Incas’ mountain strongholds and executed their emperor, Tupac Amaru, in 1572.

sec.title: Aftermath
sec.p: In what is known as the Columbian Exchange, European diseases killed off 90 percent of the Amerindian population, opening the Americas to exploration and settlement. The horse created an Amerindian mounted warrior culture. The introduction of American foods to Europe improved diets and increased population, and American silver and gold set off a price revolution, spurring the development of capitalism.
